string_table.name: pxnsnfns1111001001
string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to the Distance Learning review of Precision Runway Monitor (or PRM) approaches. This module begins with a quick refresher of the logic and approach design criteria behind PRM approaches, followed by a scenario-based look at the RNAV GPS PRM Y RWY 8L into Atlanta Hartsfield. It concludes with a short self-assessment to confirm understanding of the material presented.

Upon completing this module, you will be able to:

· Discuss the logic behind the creation and implementation of LDA and PRM type approaches

· Locate and describe any special required procedures listed on the appropriate Jeppesen plate

· Locate any PRM-related Southwest Airlines procedures in the manual system

· And describe the appropriate actions that you must take to comply with a TCAS RA that occurs concurrently with a Final Monitor Controller’s “breakout” commands

PRM approach criteria and designs are in place to deal with an essentially static infrastructure and steadily increasing volume of traffic during IFR operations at the nation’s larger airports. Normally, a minimum of 4,300 feet between centerlines is required to conduct simultaneous instrument approaches. Airports with runway designs that do not meet this minimum lose significant arrival capacity during instrument conditions.
Tap the icons to find out which approaches are appropriate for each condition.

PRM procedures and Flight Crew training mitigate the traffic problem by allowing simultaneous operations to airports with runway centerlines separated by at least 3,000 feet. Straight in approaches are either an ILS or an RNAV GPS design.

For closely spaced operations where the runways are less than 3,000 feet apart, one approach course must be offset from the other by between 2.5 and 3.0 degrees. These Simultaneous Offset Instrument Approaches (SOIA) are designed with either an LDA PRM or RNAV GPS PRM with an offset approach course.

The two runways cannot be closer than 750 feet apart. The point where the LDA or RNAV GPS course and ILS course converge to 3,000 feet establishes the offset course’s missed approach point and where the No Transgression Zone (NTZ) terminates. Between the offset approach, missed approach point, and the runway threshold, maneuver the aircraft to align with the extended runway centerline while providing collision and wake turbulence mitigation from the leading ILS aircraft. Specific cloud ceiling requirements apply to SOIA operations.

A key point to remember is that you can apply PRM principles and procedures to various types of approaches. Op Spec C052 authorizes you to use ILS/PRM, LDA/PRM, and RNAV (GPS) PRM approaches.

Let’s join a Flight Crew that is flying into Atlanta Hartsfield to see how they handle their approach.

It is early February and the Southwest Flight Crew is flying inbound to Hartsfield. The weather at altitude is beautiful but in Atlanta it is not so great.

ATIS reports a 500 foot overcast with 1 ½ miles of visibility.

It is prime time in the afternoon so to handle the volume Atlanta advises that “Simultaneous PRM approaches are in progress.” Due to diligent study habits, studious observations of DL modules, and impressive recall capabilities, the Flight Crew knows that Op Spec C052 authorizes them to conduct PRM approaches. Based upon the ATIS, NOTAMS, and past experience, they decide the RNAV GPS PRM Y Rwy 8L is their probable runway. They refer to their EFBs and select the appropriate Jeppesen plate. Staring back at them is a note in the planform view that states, “See 12-0 for RNAV (GPS) PRM Requirements”.

The Crew pulls up the Jeppesen 12-0 plate and sees a staple of PRM approaches known as the “Attention All Users” plate. This plate shows the applicable approaches and the procedures that make a PRM approach viable. Let’s take a closer look at this information.

The first paragraph indicates how serious ATC is regarding PRM approaches. If the Crew is unable to conduct a PRM approach, they need to notify ATC before they are 100 nautical miles out. If this occurs, their arrival may be delayed until ATC can coordinate appropriately to get them in.

Next, the Crew sees the required Briefing Points. The heart of PRM approaches is a discrete frequency for a Monitoring Controller. They should listen to this frequency simultaneously with the Tower Controller. The Captain pulls up the KATL 12-1A plate, sees the Monitor frequency of 126.9, and then asks the FO to set that into the #2 Com standby position and check the volume with the ATIS Frequency in the ACTIVE position. They discuss the need to make this secondary frequency active so it can be monitored after getting turned over to Atlanta tower.

Following the Briefing Points, the Crew sees a list of Expanded Procedures, which they can brief as necessary. Right up front, they notice the mention of their approach possibly switching to a standard type of approach, and the PRM requirements no longer being necessary. The Captain mentions if that event occurs, they will remain on the PRM chart; however, he makes a mental note of the following items:

· The briefed minimums and missed approach procedures will remain unchanged

· The Monitor Frequency on the #2 Com will be switched off

· A lower glide path intercept altitude may be assigned if they are switched to a new approach

The communications information that details the logic behind the Monitor Frequency dictates that all aircraft transmissions must be made on Tower Frequency. It states the Monitor Frequency should be selected when the flight is handed over to the Tower Frequency. The Monitor Frequency, coupled with the next paragraphs on the 12-0 plate, is what makes PRM possible. So what is the next bit of information for the Crew to discuss? Breakouts.

The Crew discusses the need to disconnect the autopilot and hand fly any breakout directions provided by ATC. This is to ensure the quickest response to ATC directives.

Breakout instructions usually consist of a turn with the possibility of a climb or descent. A descending breakout is only given if no other options are available to the Controller. Under no circumstances will the descent be below minimum vectoring altitude. A breakout provides the aircraft with a minimum of 1,000 feet of obstruction clearance. The cause for a breakout maneuver is generally an aircraft on the parallel approach encroaching on the No Transgression Zone.

So, with this plate briefed, the Captain and the FO move on to the Approach Plate.

Since it is the FO’s leg, he uses the Jepp 12-1A plate for his approach briefing. He notes that while this plate looks virtually identical to the normal RNAV GPS Y Rwy 8L, the inclusion of “PRM” and “Simultaneous Close Parallel” in the title clearly identifies the unique nature of this procedure.

He also sees the Monitor Frequency of 126.9 included.

Moving on to the notes, he briefs the bolded comment of “Dual VHF Com required,” which highlights the need for the Monitor Frequency. Another item he mentions that is unique to the approach is the mandated use of either a Flight Director or Autopilot to provide RNAV track guidance during simultaneous operations.

Since the boxed note about referencing the 12-0 plate has been covered, his brief moves to topics further down the page-it all looks fairly standard. Then, at the Minimums section, he notices something interesting. This PRM procedure only allows LNAV/VNAV for the approach.

The normal RNAV GPS Y Rwy 8L approach offers an LNAV only option. Clearly this procedure seeks to maximize the level of precision with which we can fly these types of approaches.

With the automation smoothly handling the descent chores and the dust settled from the pre-descent activities, the Captain decides to glance at the FOM verbiage regarding PRM approaches. Going through the bullet points, he makes a mental note of their compliance.

· The appropriate Jeppesen plates have been accessed, reviewed, briefed, and used shortly for the approach.

· The FO briefed the use of the autopilot for the approach, so he needs to pay attention to its tracking of the lateral track.

· The #2 Com is set with the Monitor Frequency and the volume has been checked. The last thing to do is select it when they are sent over to the Tower, and listen for possible breakout instructions.

· The need for hand flying any required breakout maneuver has been discussed as well as the guaranteed 1,000 feet obstruction clearances if a descending breakout maneuver is needed.

The next bullet addresses the possibility of an ATC command coupled with a TCAS RA. He thinks to himself, “Jeez, I completely forgot to consider this one!” As he reviews the FOM text, he sees that there are two directions a TCAS event needs to be considered on this approach. The first is if they encounter a TCAS RA as they are simultaneously being given a breakout maneuver, they need to follow the Controller’s turn guidance. The second is the TCAS climb or descent guidance. He notes the FOM mentions the odds of this dual event are unlikely.

The other possibility is a standalone TCAS RA. If this happens, the FOM states that the Pilot should follow the RA commands and notify the Controller of his or her actions as soon as possible. In cases like this, more than likely, a breakout command is forthcoming so the TCAS has effectively taken preemptive action. Again, the FOM states that the odds of this happening are unlikely.

The topics in this module are another example of how to apply the RRM process to a relatively common place event on the line. In terms of RISK, the previous lesson reviewed why PRM approaches are in place to solve a capacity issue that has hampered airline operations under IFR conditions at larger airports. It also reviewed how the FAA and the airline industry recognized the added risk of approaching aircraft being within closer than standard proximity to one another. Mitigation was needed to address the additional risks associated with PRM approaches.

In this scenario, the Crew accessed multiple RESOURCES to mitigate the additional risks identified with PRM approaches. The FAA accessed the precision afforded by high resolution, fast update rate radar. New procedures were designed and the use of a Monitor Controller was implemented. The industry responded with procedures to accomplish the approach design objectives, using the resources provided by the FAA, and taking advantage of aircraft technologies to maximize the precision with which the aircraft was flown.

Also, in this scenario, the Crew MANAGED various resources put in place as well as mitigated the additional risks associated with a PRM approach. Through the use of their EFBs, the Crew accessed the manual system and reviewed all the procedural aspects of their PRM approach. They used the aircraft’s various technologies to their advantage, ensuring a shared mental model. They also maintained the benefit of the TCAS by reviewing how to procedurally integrate a TCAS RA into a PRM breakout situation.
To test your understanding of the material presented, tap Next to take a short four question self-assessment.
